10.3390/land6040069;"Horse Welfare and Natural Values on Semi-Natural and Extensive Pastures in Finland: Synergies and Trade-Offs";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"In several regions in Europe
column2: the horse is becoming a common grazer on semi-natural and cultivated grasslands
column3: though the pasturing benefits for animals and biodiversity alike are not universally appreciated. The composition of ground vegetation on pastures determines the value of both the forage for grazing animals as well as the biodiversity values for species associated with the pastoral ecosystems. We studied three pastures
column4: each representing one of the management types in southern Finland (latitudes 60–61): semi-natural
column5: permanent and cultivated grassland. All have been grazed exclusively by horses for several decades. We aimed to evaluate feeding values and horses’ welfare
column6: on the one hand
column7: and impacts of horses on biodiversity in boreal conditions
column8: on the other. Though there were differences among the pastures
column9: the nutritional value of the vegetation in all three pastures met the energy and protein needs of most horse categories through the whole grazing season. Some mineral concentrations were low compared to the requirements
column10: and supplementation of Cu
column11: Zn and Na is needed to balance the mineral intake. Only minor injuries or health problems were observed. All metrics of biological values
column12: as well as number of species eaten by horses
column13: were particularly high in a semi-natural pasture compared to other pasture types. The highest ratio of species cover preferred by horses to the total cover was found in the permanent pasture
column14: while at the regularly re-seeded pasture
column15: there was a particularly high cover of species
column16: indicating low biodiversity values on grassland. There was
column18: a trade-off between the quantity of forage and biological values in pastures
column19: but not in quality. The results provide clear indication both for the suitability of the studied pasture types to horses and for grazing of horses for biodiversity management. In each pasture type
column20: specific management is needed to simultaneously achieve objectives of adequate pasturing and biodiversity. The short duration (only one grazing season) must be considered when applying the results.";"Saastamoinen

column1: 10.3390/land6040089;"Pastoralism and Land Tenure Transformation in Sub-Saharan Africa: Conflicting Policies and Priorities in Ngamiland
column3: access to land and water resources are central to pastoral livelihood activities. Policy intervention in these regions represents the outcome of concerted post-independence processes in which countries have committed to land tenure transformation as a policy objective. This was meant to create private
column4: liberal property rights to replace communal customary tenure systems which were considered to be a constraint to development. Despite these efforts
column5: decades of scientific research indicate that countries are still struggling to meet environmental sustainability objectives. Land degradation where it existed has not been halted and traditional pastoral livelihoods have been disrupted. The overall evidence base for policymaking remains weak as deficiencies in data or information on which management decisions were based led to poor policy performance. In a bid to strengthen understanding in this area
column6: this study has a dual aim: 1. Using a systematic review of the literature
column7: we examine the impact of land tenure transformation in pastoral areas in sub-Saharan Africa; 2. We analyse user-perspectives on land tenure transformation and pastoralists’ rights in Ngamiland
column8: Botswana
column9: so as to draw out the salient issues that must be addressed in order to reconcile pastoral tenure conflicts and land management in sub-Saharan Africa. Results from meta-analysis and case study show that land tenure transformation policies across pastoral areas are subject to similar challenges and consequences. Protecting pastoral land rights requires deliberate policy interventions that recognise pastoralism as a productive and efficient use of resources. Policymakers need to overcome anti-pastoral prejudice and focus on Sustainable Land Management goals. This entails establishing negotiated and flexible tenure frameworks that strengthen pastoralists’ participation in decision-making arenas by working with pastoral communities on the basis of understanding their livelihood system.";"Basupi
column10: V. Lenyeletse

column1: 10.3390/land6040088;"Determining the Frequency of Dry Lake Bed Formation in Semi-Arid Mongolia From Satellite Data";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"In the Mongolian Plateau
column3: mountains
column4: and dry lake bed surfaces may affect the process of dust storm emissions. Among these three surface types
column5: dry lake beds are considered to contribute a substantial amount of global dust emissions and to be responsible for “hot spots” of dust outbreaks. The land cover types in the study area were broadly divided into three types
column6: namely desert steppe
column7: mountains
column8: and dry lake beds
column9: by a classification based on Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) calculated from MODIS Terra satellite images
column10: and Digital Elevation Model (DEM). This dry lake beds extracting method using remote sensing offers a new technique for identifying dust hot spots and potential untapped groundwater in the dry lands of the Gobi region. In the study area
column11: frequencies of dry lake bed formation were calculated during the period of 2001 to 2014. The potential dry lake area corresponded well with the length of the river network based on hydrogeological characterization (R2 = 0.77
column12: p < 0.001). We suggest that the threshold between dry lake bed areas and the formation of ephemeral lakes in semi-arid regions is eight days of total precipitation.";"Demura

column1: 10.3390/land6040067;"Global Hotspots of Conflict Risk between Food Security and Biodiversity Conservation";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"The global challenges of food security and biodiversity are rarely addressed together
column2: though recently there has been an increasing awareness that the two issues are closely related. The majority of land available for agriculture is already used for food production
column3: but despite the productivity gains
column4: one in nine people worldwide are classified as food insecure. There is an increasing risk that addressing food insecurity through methods such as agricultural expansion or intensification could lead to biodiversity loss through destruction of habitats important for conservation. This analysis uses various indicators of biodiversity at a global scale
column5: including biodiversity hotspots
column6: total species richness
column7: and threatened and endemic species richness. Areas where high biodiversity coexists with high food insecurity or a high risk of agricultural expansion
column8: were examined and found to mainly occur in the tropics
column9: with Madagascar standing out in particular. The areas identified are especially at risk of biodiversity loss
column10: and so are global priorities for further research and for policy development to address food insecurity and biodiversity loss together.";"Molotoks
column11: Amy

column1: 10.3390/land6040066;"Agricultural Land Use Change after NAFTA in Central West Mexico";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"It has been suggested that agricultural land use change and modernization in agricultural production techniques are related to the loss of crop diversity. Two processes contribute to this loss; first is the replacement of landraces by modern varieties
column2: and second is the abandonment of traditional crops in favor of cash crops. We studied the expression of these processes in a region that is both an agro-biodiversity and cultural center and one of the most significant fruit exporters of Mexico. We analyzed agricultural change based on the transformation of cropping areas and the primary crops’ locations in Michoacán state. We examined the crop-harvested area statistics from 1950 to 2015
column3: and identified 23 crops as the most important in terms of harvested area and monetary value. After NAFTA (North American Free Trade Agreement)
column4: harvested area for nine crops changed significantly: seven crops increased
column5: and two decreased. Positive trends were observed for commercial fruits oriented to export markets
column6: and negative trends were observed for traditional crops. These crops
column7: such as beans and maize
column8: are important for food security. Additionally
column9: we analyzed how these land-use and agricultural changes overlap in zones of maize planted-area change. Using a maize-race collection database
column10: we identified three native maize races that could be at risk due to the abandonment of maize in favor of commercial crops.";"Orozco-Ramírez
column11: Quetzalcóatl

column1: 10.3390/land6040083;"Dust Storms from Degraded Drylands of Asia: Dynamics and Health Impacts";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Asian dust events are massive meteorological phenomena during which dust particles from Chinese and Mongolian deserts are blown into the atmosphere and carried by westerly winds across Northeast Asia. Recently
column2: there has been steady increase in both the frequency and the severity of Asian atmospheric dust events. Concern has been expressed regarding the potential health hazards in affected areas. The principal nature of the damage associated with Asian dust events differs between the emission (sandstorm) and downwind (air pollution) regions. In the emission region
column3: the health impacts of dust storms are reflected in the high prevalence of respiratory diseases and severe subjective symptoms. Extreme dust storm events may cause a disaster to happen. In downwind regions such as Japan
column4: analysis of Asian dust particles has shown the presence of ammonium ions
column5: sulfate ions
column6: nitrate ions
column7: and heavy metal compounds that are considered not to originate from soil. Asian dust particles have been thought to adsorb anthropogenic atmospheric pollutants during transport. Therefore
column8: Asian dust events coincide with increases in daily hospital admissions and clinical visits for allergic diseases such as asthma
column9: allergic rhinitis
column10: and conjunctivitis. Although the effect of Asian dust on human health in each region is influenced by a variety of different mechanisms
column11: human activities are partly responsible for such negative effects in many situations. We therefore need to address these environmental problems.";"Otani

column1: 10.3390/land6040082;"Identifying Hot Spots of Critical Forage Supply in Dryland Nomadic Pastoralist Areas: A Case Study for the Afar Region
column2: Ethiopia";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"This study develops a methodology to identify hot spots of critical forage supply in nomadic pastoralist areas
column3: using the Afar Region
column4: Ethiopia
column5: as a special case. It addresses two main problems. First
column6: it makes a spatially explicit assessment of fodder supply and demand extracted from a data poor environment. Fodder supply is assessed by combining rainfall-based production functions and rule-based assessment for prevailing land use. Fodder demand is based on a data consistency check of livestock statistics concerning herd size
column7: composition and geographical distribution. Second
column8: individual herd movements have to be evaluated jointly in concurrent migration patterns to assess local pressures on fodder resources. We
column9: therefore
column10: apply a transition model that relates stock levels to seasonal migration routings for all Afar sub-clans jointly so as to localize the hot spots where feed demand exceeds forage supply. Critical areas come to the fore
column11: especially
column12: near fringes of Highlands and in the southern part of the Afar. A sensitivity test shows that ‘Baseline’ scenario is close to the ‘Best’ but under ‘Worst’
column13: the Afar region would fall into despair. We conclude that the model is a useful tool to inform policy makers on critical areas in the Afar region.";"Sonneveld

column1: 10.3390/land6040081;"A Conceptual Model for Land System Dynamics as a Coupled Human–Environment System";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"This paper presents a conceptual model of land as a coupled human–environment system. Land use and land cover are incorporated as elements of the human and environment system respectively. Drivers and associated processes that influence land use
column3: and land system dynamics are incorporated within a set of sub-systems. The model includes consideration of driving sub-systems as a set of capital funds and flows
column4: and how these are influenced by linkages between processes in the human (socio-economic) and environment systems and sub-systems. The model is consistent with existing models of the biophysical earth system used by the land change
column5: earth system sciences
column6: and socio-ecological systems communities. The purposes of the model are to provide (i) a holistic framework within which descriptions
column7: models and analyses that focus on various components of land can be placed to describe and explain land systems and land system changes; and (ii) a guide for the development of more fully integrated and interdisciplinary understanding
column8: analysis and study of land use and land cover dynamics
column9: with explicit focus on relationships between human and natural systems.";"Aspinall
column10: Richard

column1: 10.3390/land6040080;"In the Land of the Dammed: Assessing Governance in Resettlement of Ghana’s Bui Dam Project";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Resettlement resulting from dam construction has raised several concerns due to the negative aftermath impacts. In Ghana
column2: the construction of three hydroelectric dams resulted in large-scale resettlements. Given the little experience that Ghana has in resettlements
column3: it is necessary for a robust monitoring structure for resettlements. However
column4: this was not available in the last resettlement undertaken for the Bui Dam Project. This paper aims at developing an assessment framework for monitoring resettlement activities on customary lands from a good governance perspective. Based on four good governance principles
column5: transparency
column6: public participation and inclusiveness
column7: equity and rule of law and accountability
column8: a good governance assessment framework is built and applied to the Bui Dam Project using a case study approach. Data were collected through interviews and focus group discussion with the key actors of the resettlement project. It was first found that the planning stage of the resettlement came out with a robust plan that was to prevent the impoverishment of the affected persons. However
column9: in the implementation of the resettlement
column10: not all good governance principles were adhered to. In conclusion
column11: it was found that by deconstructing the resettlement process with a good governance framework
column12: the problematic areas of the resettlement can be effectively differentiated between the planning and implementation phases.";"Asiama

column1: 10.3390/land6040068;"Collaborative Research on the Ecology and Management of the ‘Wulo’ Monsoon Rainforest in Wunambal Gaambera Country
column3: Australia";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Indigenous groups are increasingly combining traditional ecological knowledge and Western scientific approaches to inform the management of their lands. We report the outcomes of a collaborative research project focused on key ecological questions associated with monsoon vine thickets in Wunambal Gaambera country (Kimberley region
column4: Western Australia). The study mapped monsoon rainforests and analysed the environmental correlates of their current distribution
column5: as well as the historical drivers of patch dynamics since 1949. Remote sensing was used to chart the effectiveness of an intervention designed to re-instate Aboriginal fire regimes according to customary principles. We identified the most vulnerable patches based on size
column6: distance from neighbouring patches
column7: and fire frequency. More than 6000 rainforest patches were mapped. Most were small (<1 ha)
column8: occurring predominantly on nutrient-rich substrates (e.g.
column9: basalt) and fire-sheltered topographic settings (e.g.
column10: slopes and valleys). Rainforests with low fire frequency and no cattle were more likely to expand into surrounding long-unburnt savannas. Frequent fires and cattle did not cause substantial contraction
column11: although the latter affected rainforest understories through trampling. Fire management performed by Aboriginal rangers effectively shifted fire regimes from high-intensity late dry season fires to early dry season fires
column12: particularly in areas with clusters of vulnerable rainforests. The remote sensing methods developed in this project are applicable to the long-term monitoring of rainforest patches on Aboriginal-managed land in North Kimberley
column13: providing tools to evaluate the impacts of fire management
column15: and climate change. The study confirmed the importance of the cattle-free and rarely burnt Bougainville Peninsula as one of the most important rainforest areas in Western Australia.";"Vigilante

column1: 10.3390/land6040086;"Grassroots Innovation Using Drones for Indigenous Mapping and Monitoring";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Indigenous territories are facing increasing pressures from numerous legal and illegal activities that are pushing commodity frontiers within their limits
column2: frequently causing severe environmental degradation and threatening indigenous territorial rights and livelihoods. In Central and South America
column3: after nearly three decades of participatory mapping projects
column4: interest is mounting among indigenous peoples in the use of new technologies for community mapping and monitoring as a means of defense against such threats. Since 2014
column5: several innovative projects have been developed and implemented in the region to demonstrate and train indigenous communities in the use of small drones for territorial mapping and monitoring. In this paper
column6: we report on five projects carried out in Peru
column7: Guyana
column8: and Panama. For each one we describe the context
column9: main objectives
column10: positive outcomes
column11: challenges faced
column12: and opportunities ahead. Preliminary results are promising and have gained the interest of many indigenous societies who envision this technology as a powerful tool to protect their territories and strengthen their claims regarding specific environmental liabilities and justice issues. Based on the results presented here and a review of previous similar studies
column13: we offer a critical discussion of some of the main opportunities and challenges that we foresee regarding the use of small drones for indigenous territorial mapping and monitoring. In addition
column14: we elaborate on why a careful
column16: and progressive adoption of drones by indigenous peoples may trigger grassroots innovations in ways conducive to greater environmental justice and sustainability.";"Paneque-Gálvez

column1: 10.3390/land6040085;"Simulating Stakeholder-Based Land-Use Change Scenarios and Their Implication on Above-Ground Carbon and Environmental Management in Northern Thailand";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"The objective of this study was to examine whether the coupling of a land-use change (LUC) model with a carbon-stock accounting approach and participatory procedures can be beneficial in a data-limited environment to derive implications for environmental management. Stakeholder-based LUC scenarios referring to different storylines of agricultural intensification and reforestation were simulated to explore their impact on above-ground carbon (AGC) for a period of twenty years (2009–2029). The watershed of Mae Sa Mai
column2: Northern Thailand was used as a case study for this purpose. Coupled model simulations revealed that AGC stocks could be increased by up to 1.7 Gg C through expansion of forests or orchard areas. A loss of up to 0.4 Gg C would occur if vegetable production continue to expand at the expense of orchard and fallow areas. The coupled model approach was useful due to its moderate data demands
column3: enabling the comparison of land-use types differing in AGC build-up rates and rotation times. The scenario analysis depicted clear differences in the occurrence of LUC hotspots
column4: highlighting the importance of assessing the impact of potential future LUC pathways at the landscape level. The use of LUC scenarios based on local stakeholder scenarios offer a higher credibility for climate mitigation strategies but also underline the need to co-design policy frameworks that acknowledge the heterogeneity of stakeholder needs and environmental management frameworks.";"Lippe
column5: Melvin

column1: 10.3390/land6040084;"Assessing the Sustainability of EU Timber Consumption Trends: Comparing Consumption Scenarios with a Safe Operating Space Scenario for Global and EU Timber Supply";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"The growing demand for wood to meet EU renewable energy targets has increasingly come under scrutiny for potentially increasing EU import dependence and inducing land use change abroad
column2: with associated impacts on the climate and biodiversity. This article builds on research accounting for levels of primary timber consumption—e.g.
column3: toward forest footprints—and developing reference values for benchmarking sustainability—e.g.
column4: toward land use targets—in order to improve systemic monitoring of timber and forest use. Specifically
column5: it looks at future trends to assess how current EU policy may impact forests at an EU and global scale. Future demand scenarios are based on projections derived and adapted from the literature to depict developments under different scenario assumptions. Results reveal that by 2030
column6: EU consumption levels on a per capita basis are estimated to be increasingly disproportionate compared to the rest of the world. EU consumption scenarios based on meeting around a 40% share of the EU renewable energy targets with timber would overshoot both the EU and global reference value range for sustainable supply capacities in 2030. Overall
column7: findings support literature pointing to an increased risk of problem shifting relating to both how much and where timber needed for meeting renewable energy targets is sourced. It is argued that a sustainable level of timber consumption should be characterized by balance between supply (what the forest can provide on a sustainable basis) and demand (how much is used on a per capita basis
column8: considering the concept of fair shares). To this end
column9: future research should close data gaps
column10: increase methodological robustness and address the socio-political legitimacy of the safe operating space concept towards targets in the future. A re-use of timber within the economy should be supported to increase supply options.";"O’Brien
column11: Meghan

column1: 10.3390/land6040087;"Bequest of the Norseman—The Potential for Agricultural Intensification and Expansion in Southern Greenland under Climate Change";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"The increase of summer temperatures and a prolonged growing season increase the potential for agricultural land use for subarctic agriculture. Nevertheless
column2: land use at borderline ecotones is influenced by more factors than temperature and the length of the growing season
column3: for example soil quality
column4: as the increasing lengths of dry periods during vegetation season can diminish land use potential. Hence
column5: this study focuses on the quality of the soil resource as possible limiting factor for land use intensification in southern Greenland. Physical and chemical soil properties of cultivated grasslands
column6: reference sites and semi-natural birch and grassland sites were examined to develop a soil quality index and to identify the suitability of soils for a sustainable intensification and expansion of the agriculture. The study revealed that soils in the study area are generally characterized by a low effective cation exchange capacity (CECeff) (3.7 ± 5.0 meq 100 g−1)
column7: low pH CaCl2 (4.6 ± 0.4) and low clay and silt content (3.0 ± 1.0% and 38.2 ± 4.7%
column8: respectively). Due to the high amount of coarse fraction (59.1 ± 5.8%) and the low amount of soil nutrients
column9: an increasing threat of dry spells for soils and yield could be identified. Further
column10: future land use intensification and expansion bears a high risk for concomitant effects
column11: namely further soil acidification
column12: nutrient leaching and soil degradation processes. However
column13: results of the soil quality index also indicate that sites which were already used by the Norseman (980s–1450) show the best suitability for agricultural use. Thus
column14: these areas offer a possibility to expand agricultural land use in southern Greenland.";"Caviezel

column1: 10.3390/land6040076;"Landscape Risk Assessment Model and Decision Support System for the Protection of the Natural and Cultural Heritage in the Eastern Mediterranean Area";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"In recent years
column2: the competition of uses for scarce and highly valuable natural resources
column3: and the frequency and severity of natural and technological disasters have increased
column4: and this trend is likely to worsen in the years to come. In the Mediterranean area
column5: especially in its Eastern part
column6: the high human exploitation driven by different economic sectors and interests is resulting in intensive use of the land and its resources. Tourism intensification
column7: rapid growth of urban settlement and related sprawl
column8: movement and displacement of populations
column9: rural abandonment
column10: and adoption of different agricultural techniques are profoundly and rapidly changing the landscape character of the East Mediterranean. In view of the risks to cultural and natural heritage
column11: a Landscape Risk Assessment Model (LRA) and Decision Support System (LDSS) were developed through the MedScapes-ENPI project. This paper reports the experience conducted at the Landscape Design and Ecosystem Management Department (LDEM) in the American University of Beirut (AUB) in developing the two tools
column12: LRA and LDSS. It aims to provide insight into the methodology designed and tested during the length of the project to take into account the protection of landscapes of particular interest as well as the rational planning of all the landscapes with special emphasis on the use of natural resources. The assessment was applied in the study area of each partner country of the ENPI project
column13: allowing for a better understanding of the implications in land-use and conservation decision-making.";"Trovato

column1: 10.3390/land6040077;"Water Rights on Community Lands: LandMark’s Findings from 100 Countries";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"This paper analyzes whether national laws acknowledge indigenous peoples and other rural communities in 100 countries as owners of waters that arise within their lands. Results derive from information collected by LandMark to score the legal status of community land tenure. Findings are positive; half of all countries recognize communities as lawful possessors of water on their lands. Three quarters permit communities to manage the distribution and use of water on their lands. While 71 percent of countries declare water to be a public resource
column2: this belies the substantial existence of privately owned water. In 29 percent of countries
column3: private water is an identified legal category
column4: and in many other countries obtainable rights to water are sufficiently substantial to imply lawful possession. Communities are beneficiaries mainly where customary rights are accorded status as property rights
column5: or where ownership of public lands and water are devolved to rural collectives. However
column6: opposite trends of nationalization and regulation of water suggest that while legal recognition of community land ownership may rise in the future
column7: this will not necessarily include waters on the land. Irrespective of tenure
column8: rural communities in 72 of 77 countries (93.5 percent) are legally assured access to water for domestic purposes. This is consistent with the rising definition of safe drinking water as a human right
column9: although access does not necessarily come free of cost.";"Alden Wily
column10: Liz

column1: 10.3390/land6040074;"Effect of Climate and Agricultural Land Use Changes on UK Feed Barley Production and Food Security to the 2050s";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Currently
column2: the UK has a high self-sufficiency rate in barley production. This paper assessed the effects of projected climate and land use changes on feed barley production and
column3: consequently
column4: on meat supply in the UK from the 2030s to the 2050s. Total barley production under projected land use and climate changes ranged from 4.6 million tons in the 2030s to 9.0 million tons in the 2050s. From these
column5: the projected feed barley supply ranged from approximately 2.3 to 4.6 million tons from the 2030s to the 2050s
column6: respectively. The results indicate that while UK spring barley production will thrive under
column7: and benefit from climate change
column8: total land area allocated to barley production will ultimately determine self-sufficiency. Without expansion in the area of land and/or further significant increases in yields
column9: the UK may face large deficits in domestic feed barley production and
column10: for that matter
column11: meat supply in the future. Hence
column12: agricultural and food security policy needs to consider
column14: the effect of agricultural land use change on key crops
column15: such as barley. Even though the UK can import feed barley or meat to address the deficits observed in this study
column16: the question that needs to be addressed is where all that import will come from.";"Yawson

column1: 10.3390/land6040075;"Impact of the Household Registration System on Farmers’ Rural Housing Land Use Decisions in China";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"By using the difference-in-difference method and introducing control variables
column2: this study investigates the effect of the household registration system (hukou) on farmers’ willingness to transfer rural housing land based on survey data of farmers in Chongqing and Wuhan
column3: China. The results show that the effect of household registration system reform is significant at the 1% level
column4: which indicates that household registration system reform significantly influences farmers’ willingness to transfer rural housing land in the experimental area
column5: leading to an increase in the share of farmers willing to transfer such land by 37%. In areas with greater efforts to reform the household registration system
column6: farmers are more willing to transfer rural housing land. Moreover
column7: the per capita non-farm income of rural households and compensation standard have a significantly positive correlation with farmers’ willingness.";"Zhu

column1: 10.3390/land6040072;"Monitoring Changes in Croplands Due to Water Stress in the Krishna River Basin Using Temporal Satellite Imagery";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Remote sensing-based assessments of large river basins such as the Krishna
column2: which supplies water to many states in India
column3: are useful for operationally monitoring agriculture
column4: especially basins that are affected by abiotic stress. Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) time series products can be used to understand cropland changes at the basin level due to abiotic stresses
column5: especially water scarcity. Spectral matching techniques were used to identify land use/land cover (LULC) areas for two crop years: 2013–2014
column6: which was a normal year
column8: which was a water stress year. Water stress-affected crop areas were categorized into three classes—severe
column9: moderate and mild—based on the normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) and intensity of damage assessed through field sampling. Furthermore
column10: ground survey data were used to assess the accuracy of MODIS-derived classification individual products. Water inflows into and outflows from the Krishna river basin during the study period were used as direct indicators of water scarcity/availability in the Krishna Basin. Furthermore
column11: ground survey data were used to assess the accuracy of MODIS-derived LULC classification of individual year products. Rainfall data from the tropical rainfall monitoring mission (TRMM) was used to support the water stress analysis. The nine LULC classes derived using the MODIS temporal imagery provided overall accuracies of 82% for the cropping year 2013–2014 and 85% for the year 2015–2016. Kappa values are 0.78 for 2013–2014 and 0.82 for 2015–2016. MODIS-derived cropland areas were compared with national statistics for the cropping year 2013–2014 with a R2 value of 0.87. Results show that both rainfed and irrigated areas in 2015–2016 saw significant changes that will have significant impacts on food security. It has been also observed that the farmers in the basin tend to use lower inputs and labour per ha during drought years. Among all
column12: access to water is the major driver determining the crop choice and extent of input-use in the basin.";"Murthy Reddi

column1: 10.3390/land6040073;"Land Cover Change in Northern Botswana: The Influence of Climate
column3: and Elephants on Semi-Arid Savanna Woodlands";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Complex couplings and feedback among climate
column4: fire
column5: and herbivory drive short- and long-term patterns of land cover change (LCC) in savanna ecosystems. However
column6: understanding of spatial and temporal LCC patterns in these environments is limited
column7: particularly for semi-arid regions transitional between arid and more mesic climates. Here
column8: we use post-classification analysis of Landsat TM (1990)
column10: and OLI (2013) satellite imagery to classify and assess net and gross LCC for the Chobe District
column18: and six protected forest reserves). We then evaluate spatiotemporal patterns of LCC in relation to precipitation
column20: 2001–2013) from the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS)
column21: and dry season elephant (Loxodonta africana) aerial survey data (2003
column24: 2013). Woodland cover declined over the study period by 1514 km2 (16.2% of initial class total)
column25: accompanied by expansion of shrubland (1305 km2
column27: 20.3%). Net LCC differed importantly in protected areas
column28: with higher woodland losses observed in forest reserves compared to the CNP. Loss of woodland was also higher in communally-managed land for the study period
column29: despite gains from 2003–2013. Gross (class) changes were characterized by extensive exchange between woodland and shrubland during both time steps
column30: and a large expansion of shrubland into grassland and bare ground from 2003–2013. MODIS active fire detections were highly variable from year to year and among the different protected areas
column31: ranging from 1.8 fires*year−1/km2 in the Chobe Forest Reserve to 7.1 fires*year−1/km2 in the Kasane Forest Reserve Extension. Clustering and timing of dry season fires suggests that ignitions were predominately from anthropogenic sources. Annual fire count was significantly related to total annual rainfall (p = 0.009
column33: with a 41% increase in average fire occurrence in years when rainfall exceeded long-term mean annual precipitation (MAP). Loss of woodland was significantly associated with fire in locations experiencing 15 or more ignitions during the period 2001–2013 (p = 0.024). Although elephant-mediated damage is often cited as a major cause of woodland degradation in northern Botswana
column34: we observed little evidence of unsustainable pressure on woodlands from growing elephant populations. Our data indicate broad-scale LCC processes in semi-arid savannas in Southern Africa are strongly coupled to environmental and anthropogenic forcings. Increased seasonal variability is likely to have important effects on the distribution of savanna plant communities due to climate-fire feedbacks. Long-term monitoring of LCC in these ecosystems is essential to improving land use planning and management strategies that protect biodiversity
column35: as well as traditional cultures and livelihoods under future climate change scenarios for Southern Africa.";"Fox

column1: 10.3390/land6040070;"Mapping Land Cover and Estimating the Grassland Structure in a Priority Area of the Chihuahuan Desert";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"A field characterization of the grassland vegetation structure
column2: represented by the coverage of grass canopy (CGC) and the grass height
column3: was carried out during three years (2009–2011) in a priority area for the conservation of grasslands of North America. Landsat Thematic Mapper (TM5) images were selected and the information of reflectance was obtained based on the geographical location of each field-sampling site. Linear models
column4: constructed with field and satellite data
column5: with high coefficients of determination for CGC (R2 = 0.81
column6: R2 = 0.81 and R2 = 0.72) and grass height (R2 = 0.82
column7: R2 = 0.79 and R2 = 0.73) were obtained. The maps showed a good level of CGC (>25%) and grass height (>25 cm)
column8: except for the year 2009
column9: which presented the lowest values of grass height in the area. According to the Kappa Index
column10: a moderate concordance among the three CGC maps was presented (0.49–0.59). Conversely
column11: weak and moderate concordances were found among the grass height maps (0.36–0.59). It was observed that areas with a high CGC do not necessarily correspond to areas with greater grass height values. Based on the data analyzed in this study
column12: the grassland areas are highly dynamic
column13: structurally heterogeneous and the spatial distribution of the variables does not show a definite pattern. From the information generated
column14: it is possible to determine those areas that are the most important for monitoring to then establish effective strategies for the conservation of these grasslands and the protection of threatened migratory bird species.";"Rodríguez-Maturino

column1: 10.3390/land6040071;"Investigating the Diversity and Variability of Eastern Mediterranean Landscapes";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"The aim of the paper is to examine the variability of eastern Mediterranean landscapes using a common mapping framework relying on Landscape Character Mapping (LCM). LCM was adapted to the region’s specificities placing emphasis on the area’s coastal nature
column3: land use
column4: in particular pastoral tradition
column5: and settlement patterns
column6: an important output of this study. We selected six study areas
column7: in four countries namely Cyprus
column8: Greece
column9: Jordan and Lebanon
column10: based on their rich cultural and natural heritage
column11: covering a NW to SE gradient of both environmental and cultural settings. We used commonly employed landscape metrics to quantify landscape diversity in the study areas. Similarity in landscape types among study area was measured using Sørensen similarity index. The Kruskall–Walis test was used to test the variability among countries in terms of landscape character variation due to physical and cultural factors. Linear regression was used to assess whether landscape diversity increases with area size. The work has identified and mapped a total of 69 landscape types
column12: of which 18 are rare. Rare landscape types were related to specific geomorphology or intensive anthropogenic activities
column13: which do not occur elsewhere in the East Mediterranean region. The highest similarity was recorded between islands and between mountainous areas. The larger the area the higher is its landscape diversity. This works fills a gap in Mediterranean and sets a benchmark standard for landscape characterization work in the East Mediterranean
column14: so as to enable much greater consistency between countries in future landscape mapping exercises and
column16: facilitate trans-boundary cooperation in landscape-scale nature and culture conservation.";"Vogiatzakis

column5: through a purposive comparative research survey of four case studies: Cyprus
column6: Greece

column8: performed in the broader context of the MEDSCAPES ENPI-MED project (www.enpi-medscapes.org)
column9: the paper draws together the insights and concerns of a total of 61 public entities
column10: private entrepreneurs
column11: academicians and NGO representatives
column15: in these four countries. The results point to significant commonalities among them and begin to show relational and synthetic nature of the interrelationship between humans and the landscape
column16: as it developed in the context of the local and regional geographies and histories of this broader region
column17: affected by and involving a series of relevant geophysical

column1: 10.3390/land6040091;"Constraining the Deforestation History of Europe: Evaluation of Historical Land Use Scenarios with Pollen-Based Land Cover Reconstructions";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Anthropogenic land cover change (ALCC) is the most important transformation of the Earth system that occurred in the preindustrial Holocene
column3: water and sediment cycles
column4: biodiversity and the provision of ecosystem services and regional and global climate. For example
column5: anthropogenic deforestation in preindustrial Eurasia may have led to feedbacks to the climate system: both biogeophysical
column6: regionally amplifying winter cold and summer warm temperatures
column7: and biogeochemical
column8: stabilizing atmospheric CO     2     concentrations and thus influencing global climate. Quantification of these effects is difficult
column9: however
column10: because scenarios of anthropogenic land cover change over the Holocene vary widely
column11: with increasing disagreement back in time. Because land cover change had such widespread ramifications for the Earth system
column12: it is essential to assess current ALCC scenarios in light of observations and provide guidance on which models are most realistic. Here
column13: we perform a systematic evaluation of two widely-used ALCC scenarios (KK10 and HYDE3.1) in northern and part of central Europe using an independent
column14: pollen-based reconstruction of Holocene land cover (REVEALS). Considering that ALCC in Europe primarily resulted in deforestation
column15: we compare modeled land use with the cover of non-forest vegetation inferred from the pollen data. Though neither land cover change scenario matches the pollen-based reconstructions precisely
column16: KK10 correlates well with REVEALS at the country scale
column17: while HYDE systematically underestimates land use with increasing magnitude with time in the past. Discrepancies between modeled and reconstructed land use are caused by a number of factors
column18: including assumptions of per-capita land use and socio-cultural factors that cannot be predicted on the basis of the characteristics of the physical environment
column21: the location of urban areas and social organization.";"Kaplan

column1: 10.3390/land6040078;"Impact of Soil Depth and Topography on the Effectiveness of Conservation Practices on Discharge and Soil Loss in the Ethiopian Highlands";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Restoration of degraded landscapes through the implementation of soil and water conservation practices is considered a viable option to increase agricultural production by enhancing ecosystems. However
column3: little information is available on the impact of conservation practices despite wide scale implementation. The objective of this research was to document the effect of conservation practices on discharge and sediment concentration and load in watersheds that have different soil depths and topography. Precipitation
column4: discharge
column5: and sediment concentration were measured from 2010 to 2012 in two watersheds in close proximity and located in the Lake Tana basin
column6: Ethiopia: Tikur-Wuha and Guale watersheds. The Tikur-Wuha watershed has deep soils and a gentle slope stream channel. The Guale watershed has shallow soils and a steep slope stream channel. In early 2011
column7: the local community installed upland conservation measures consisting of stone and soil bunds
column8: waterways
column9: cutoff drains
column10: infiltration furrows
column11: gully rehabilitation
column12: and enclosures. The results show that conservation practices marginally decreased direct runoff in both watersheds and increased base flow in the Tikur-Wuha watershed. Average sediment concentration decreased by 81% in Tikur-Wuha and 45% in Guale. The practices intended to increase infiltration were most effective in the Tikur-Wuha watershed because the deep soil could store the infiltrated water and release it over a longer period of time after the rainy season than the steeper Guale watershed with shallow soils.";"Akale

column1: 10.3390/land6040079;"What’s (Not) on the Map: Landscape Features from Participatory Sketch Mapping Differ from Local Categories Used in Language";"Volume 6 Issue 4";"Participatory mapping of local land use as the basis for planning and decision-making has become widespread around the globe. However
column2: still relatively little is known about the conceptual underpinnings of geographic information produced through participatory mapping in given cultural and linguistic settings. In this paper
column3: we therefore address the seemingly simple question of what is (not) represented on maps through an exploratory case study comparing land use categories participants represented on sketch maps with categories elicited through more language-focused ethnographic fieldwork. To explore landscape categorization
column4: we conducted sketch mapping with 29 participants and in-depth ethnographic fieldwork with 19 participants from the Takana indigenous people in the Bolivian Amazon. Sketch mapping resulted in 74 different feature types
column5: while we elicited 156 landscape categories used in language
column6: of which only 23 overlapped with feature types from the sketch mapping. Vegetation categories were highly diversified in language but seldom represented on maps
column7: while more obviously anthropogenic features were represented on sketch maps. Furthermore
column8: participants seldom drew culturally important landscape categories such as fallow plots or important plant harvesting sites on maps
column9: with important potential consequences for natural resource management.";"Wartmann
